Award.AwardTitle: SHARIAH WITHOUT COURTS: A STUDY OF ISLAMIC JUDICIAL PRACTICES IN ENGLAND

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. John R. Bowen (Washington University in St Louis) will undertake research on England's Shariah Councils. Across Europe and North America, some Muslims have proposed the creation of religious tribunals to mediate in family and other disputes. These proposals often meet with opposition from those concerned about lack of transparent procedures, possible patriarchal attitudes towards women and children, and the effects of introducing political Islam into Western law. But in England, Muslims already have created institutions for mediating disputes that are based on Islamic norms or shar√Æ`a. The English case, with its advanced Islamic institutional development, thus provides an instructive case for both social scientific discussions and public policy debates.

The researcher will conduct his investigations primarily at three English councils, two tribunals that offers mediation and one tribunal that offers binding arbitration. He will gather data from observations, interviews, and analyses of decisions, with a focus on how Islamic judges deliberate and reach decisions. Attention will be paid especially to determining the extent to which prior experience of these judges in their countries of origin shapes what they do in England, and to what extent judges craft their decisions around the English social and legal context.

The research forms part of a larger scientific project comparing Islamic deliberative processes across three Western countries: the United States, France, and Great Britain. The research is important because it will add to social scientific knowledge of how Islamic, and, by extension, other religious quasi-legal institutions function in varying contexts. Findings will contribute needed information to public policy debates about the role of religious courts in Western secular societies. The results will be disseminated in planned public lectures and in publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The council activities raise a number of pressing questions concerning Islam, law, and society in Western countries. Does a system of religious tribunals threaten the neutrality or the unity of law? The Islamic scholars sitting on these councils come from diverse religious backgrounds; how are they able to reach consensual decisions? Put another way, how do Muslims of different convictions construct, through a deliberative process, an Islamic law for England? On what rests its legitimacy, if indeed it is considered legitimate by Muslims?  The materials gathered allowed the PI to focus on four aspects of their activities: procedure, deliberation, justification, and legal equivalence.

Procedure: how a divorce certificate is produced. The London tribunal is in a near-continual process of modifying procedures, in which they justify changes in terms of Islamic texts, practical experience, and the workings of the civil courts. In their self-conception, procedures guarantee validity and thus legitimacy in the eyes of British Muslim users of the court, South Asian Islamic judges and lawyers, and also British judges and lawyers. The scholars draw on Islamic normative repertoires and also accounts of social practices in Pakistan or Bangladesh to translate information in dossiers or interviews into facts “relevant” to their decision. They debate among themselves about the relevance of certain of these elements. The PI also took into account the ways in which women seeking divorce regard the councils. The London and Birmingham sessions provided a striking contrast in which female versus male scholars treat the mainly female petitioners, and the responses of these women to their experience.

Deliberation: how 4-6 scholars of differing backgrounds sitting together can produce a decision. Answering this question relied on analysis of recordings and interviews. The scholars engaged in discussing a case often argue over which rules should be used, and also what the function of a shariah council ought to be in a non-Muslim country. In these arguments, they bring to bear either explicitly or implicitly their own background differences, both theological (Deobandi, Ahl ul-hadîth, and Salafi schools), and cultural (Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, or elsewhere). The PI analyzed the points at which these “meta-normative” disputes arise and how they are resolved or (more usually) elided.

Justification: how do scholars justify their decisions to each other, to those involved in the process (wives and husbands and their families), and to a broader public? On their websites, in community discussions, and in (sometimes heated) telephone calls, the London and Birmingham scholars strategically draw from different sectors of the Islamic tradition (for example, the Hanafi legal school versus the often opposed work of Ibn Taimiyya) in order to justify a decision. They shape their decisions and justifications in ways intended to, first, produce a socially-useful result, and, secondly, minimize criticism of the tribunals. Several detailed matters (for example, distinguishing between a khula divorce and a faskh annulment) are handled in ways that are purposefully ambiguous in order to accomplish these two ends. Scholars do not so much “follow rules” as they “craft outcomes” in a pragmatic fashion. (The Sufi saint's legitimacy stems from his sanctity and is deployed in quite distinct ways.)
